the game. And so that means that for the
time being, not much is going to make
its way to us, the players. In our

to let you know upfront, I feel

A major shout out and thank you to our
channel members. As always, your

more appreciated than you know. Without
further ado, however, let's dive in. So,
to begin, let's just get caught up to
speed. Have there been any updates on
the project since we last spoke of it at
the beginning of 2025? Technically, but
not really. Sort of. It's more of a
reading between the lines situation, if
you catch my drift. As far as actual
comments from the team, just about the
only notable acknowledgements we got
throughout 2025 was from Julian Gity,
who is currently serving as executive
producer for the Division brand at
large, but is also overseeing Division 3
development. Back in August, around the

attend Gamescom, someone replied to him

a while. Have you found a team making
Division 3?" And his one-word response
was, "We," which if you don't know means
yes in French. So yeah, maybe now you
can begin to see why I didn't have much
of a reason to make an update video
throughout 2025, but I wanted to
highlight this comment in particular as
it leads us into what is probably the

and that is Massive Entertainment

the development studio that created The
Division IP and has spearheaded

leading development on The Division 3,
but this time last year their focus as a
studio was split. We knew they were
working on The Division 3 as it was
confirmed all the way back in 2023.
However, it was widely believed that
they also were working on an additional
AAA project among other evidence. At the
time, there was a multitude of job
hirings listed, some that explicitly
stated The Division 3 as the project,
but many that were for an unannounced
title. This wasn't a huge shock given
the studio had grown enough to support
two AAA teams with development of Avatar
Frontiers of Pandora and Star Wars
Outlaws running concurrently throughout
much of the early 2020s. But it was
definitely one aspect that left some
Division fans disheartened, myself
included. We'd hoped that we might see
them return to their roots after the
release of Avatar and Star Wars and
commit the entirety of their resources
back to The Division. Things began to
change though around the middle of 2025.
All those job listings that had been up,
very suddenly they all vanished. Reports
came out about the cancellation of a
Star Wars Outlaws 2, which while not
confirmed to be in development at
Massive, logically seems like it would
have been there. And although I was a
surprise to hear that the Avatar team
had been cooking up an all-new DLC for
the 2023 game, which launched last month
to coincide with the new Avatar movie
that released, creative director Omar
Buelli parttooken in Ask Me Anything on
the game's official Reddit page in which
he confirmed that there are currently no
plans for future content after the
release of the newest DLC. So, if no new
AAA project is spinning up and if
Outlaws and Avatar content has all
wrapped up, that just leaves one thing,
Division. And I think all of this is
well encapsulated in this press release
that Massive put out back in October.
Now, this initially caused a lot of
confusion and push back from the public
as the second paragraph in particular
announces that the studio is enacting a
voluntary career transition program. uh
which to many just sounded like a fancy
corporate way to avoid saying layoffs.
And to be clear, I do not want to nor
intend to ever defend any kind of
initiative that causes hardworking
developers to lose jobs against their
will. However, now having some of this
additional context, and after speaking
to a few sources within Massive at the
time, in actuality, this is all far less
nefarious than many made it out to be.
The truth is that Massive went through
some pretty radical transformation
across the past decade. They went from a
studio working all united as one on a
military shooter. Then Avatar spun up,
later Star Wars, transitioning them to
become a much more fantastical licensed
game studio and one that was handling
two major games at once. But now the
pendulum has swung back. They're
shifting back to The Division and
refocusing into one team. And so that
not only introduces the possibility of
some roles being overcrowded as there's
now just one main project to focus on,
but it also means that for many who join
the studio in the past 5 years thinking
they'd get to work on one type of game,
that's now been flipped entirely on its
head. So all of that is to say that it
is my understanding that no huge wave of
layoffs occurred as some tried to spin.
rather those who do not want to be
committed to working at a division
focused studio for the foreseeable
future have the opportunity to look
elsewhere for work and get some
assistance in doing so. And that in turn
might help Massive in figuring out the
jigsaw puzzle of where to place
everybody under the new paradigm. The
bottom line for all of this and what I
think stands out most for Division fans
and those who are anticipating The
Division 3, as of 2026, Massive is back
to being a Division focused studio. With
that same press release confirming that
they are committed to The Division 2,
the Division 2 Survivors, the Division
Resurgence, and The Division 3. And at
least largely those working on these
projects have chosen to. They're
committed and invested in this IP. And I
think having developers who hold genuine
passion for what they work on is a
hugely underrated boon in game
development. So with it having been over
a year since Groundwork began on The
Division 3 and with Massive now being on
the other side of realigning the studio
to focus on the game as its one core AAA
project, that leaves us in a pretty good
position as it means that the likely
hundreds of developers in place working
on it can really begin to pick up the
pace. That then takes us to the
internet's number one question. When is

day about what's happening with
development, who is working on what,
yada yada, but all people really care
about is when do I get to play it? Well,
obviously we still don't have any
official release date or window here at
the beginning of 2026. In my video last
year, I gave the prediction that I
believe The Division 3 would release in
2028, or if not then, then certainly no
sooner than 2028. And for now, that is
still what I'm sticking with. What's
difficult as far as predicting at this
point in time is that we have very
little to go off of. And by that, I
mean, ever since Division 3 was
announced, I've seen people offer wildly
optimistic predictions and timelines for
release, largely fueled by the fact that
it only took Division 2 3 years to make
and ship. What you have to keep in mind,
though, is that there are some big
differences between the leap from 1 to
two and what will be the leap from two
to three. Division 2 did not have to
make a console or technological
generation leap. It released on the Xbox
One and the PS4, same as the Division 1,
and only implemented some more subtle
engine improvements on the back end.
Comparatively though, Division 3 has the
potential of pushing being two full
generations later by the time it finally
releases. And in the past nearly 7 years
since The Division 2 came out, a lot has
changed with the expectations, features,
and technology used for AAA game
development. What we also don't have a
very clear picture of is what, if any,
additional Ubisoft studios are
supporting Division 3 development. One
of the only reasons The Division 2 was
able to be cranked out in under three
years is because it had at its peak over
1,000 developers working on it with
multiple support studios dedicating
major amounts of resources to aid
Massive with their efforts. Today,
things are very different. Redstorm,
which was for many years the foremost
Division support studio, is now a shell
of its former self, having laid off many
longtime Division veterans and moving
what few members it has left onto
support for Rainbow 6. That's just one
example. But overall, Ubisoft is in a
time of major transformation as well,
and I don't think we can count on all of
this outside support being readily
available to pitch in. So again, while I
think 2028 is the absolute earliest that
anyone should expect to see The Division
3 release, it wouldn't shock me if it
ends up slipping into 2029. We'll just
have to wait and see what we learn. So,
I know you're probably hearing those
dates and thinking, "Well, that sucks.
Looks like we're not going to be hearing
anything about the game for a long

where we might get our very first
concrete details about The Division 3 in
2026. And that's because we have a very
